Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Accelerator Physics and Synchrotron Radiation Science
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports the REU site at the Cornell Laboratory for Accelerator Based ScienceS and Education (CLASSE). This site will involve ten students per year in summer research projects at the Laboratory. Supported by the NSF, the Laboratory has a constellation of programs including accelerator physics, synchrotron radiation research, and microwave superconductivity. Although the research of this REU is focused on understanding the fundamental physics of beams and accelerators and the uses of the radiation they produce, the techniques and technologies utilized are applicable to a much wider range of scientific careers. The student participants will have full access to the resources of the Laboratory and University. They will work on a range of projects that advance the Laboratory's scientific mission, as well as giving the students the opportunity to experience the excitement and challenge of frontier research, acquire new skills, and meet researchers at all career stages.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research Experiences for Undergraduate (REU) were offered to 32 American students from universities across the US at the Cornell Laboratory for Accelerator-based ScienceS and Education (CLASSE). This laboratory, and therefore the student’s research, covered topics of particle accelerators for elementary-particle physics or for the creation of x-rays, and on utilizing such x-rays for material analysis in various scientific fields. Each student actively participated in research, showed results in a professional presentation, and authored a scientific report. Furthermore, each student participated in outreach activities educating the general public about the physical sciences. A large majority of student participants left this experience with the goal of pursuing a PhD in physics research. Recognizing the importance of particle accelerators to the economic and military security of the nation, educating these students and helping their career paths have been very worthwhile efforts. 

 

The students' names and their project titles were:

 

Ryan Badman (Syracuse University), “ILC Damping-Ring RD with the Cornell Electron Storage Ring Test Accelerator”. H used the ECLOUD program to match data from witness bunch scans that studied the relative cloud density at different bunch spacings to measure cloud decay in CESR over time.

 

Christie Chiu (Massachusetts Institute of Technology), “Dark Current Simulations for the Cornell ERL”. She simulated the field emission of electrons in superconducting cavities, following the path of thousands of electrons to find their energy gain with time and their impact location when they hit the surface of the cavity. This yielded temperature increases in the superconductor and the electron radiation load along the cavity walls. Lisa Nash used this data to calculate particle showers resulting from these electrons, estimating the x-ray and neutron radiation load outside a superconducting Linac.

 

Jennifer Chu (Carnegie Mellon University), “Using Tune Shifts to Evaluate Electron Cloud Effects on Beam Dynamics at CESR-TA”. She compared tune-shift from Electron Clouds in simulations to data from CESR to find the optimal parameters that describe the physics of electron clouds.

 

Robert Cope (Colorado State University), “Image Analysis for Dispersive X-ray Emission Spectroscopy (XES)”. Simulated new monochromator optics, and developed a new calibration procedure for Laue diffraction, he also improved analysis tools for the CHESS C1 beamline.

Morgan Dixon (Carleton University), “Activation Studies of GaAs Photocathode”. He analyzed the preparation and activation processes used to create negative electron affinity GaAs photocathodes for Cornell’s ERL injector prototype.

 

Shannon Hughes (University of Notre Dame), “Reentrant Multicell Cavity with Improved HOM Properties”. She sought to reduce non-propagating (trapped) higher-order modes in multicell cavities with 90? cell wall slope by finding an optimal shape for superconducting cavities.

 

Kevin Kelly (University of Notre Dame), “Position Detection Accuracy of X-ray Video Beam Position Measurement”. He used a Video BPM on an LED Light Source on an optics bench and compared against Monte Carlo software to understand how CCD impacts measurements of the beam position.

 

Stephanie Milazzo (Rhodes College), “Deposition of Molecular Thin Films Relevant for Organic Electronics”. She tested solution-based film deposition techniques on several polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons with the goal of obtaining excellent molecular orientation.
